      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)

      • isValid

        public static boolean isValid(java.lang.String url)
        Validates an absolute url. This method uses a regular expression, which we'll discuss in Adv Topics. This method is not bullet-proof, but it will serve the purpose of this exercise.
        Parameters:
        url -
        Returns:
        Returns true if the url parameter is a valid absolute url, returns false otherwise

      • getProtocol

        public static java.lang.String getProtocol(java.lang.String url)
        Extracts the protocol portion of the url. Note that the protocol is the first part of a url and is always followed by a semi-colon.
        Parameters:
        url -
        Returns:

      • getHost

        public static java.lang.String getHost(java.lang.String url)
        Extracts the host portion of the url. Note that the host potrion of a url always starts just after the two forward slashes (//) and continues until the next forward slash. Also note that the host is also called the domain name, and/or the server name.
        Parameters:
        url -
        Returns:

      • getQueryString

        public static java.lang.String getQueryString(java.lang.String url)
        Extracts the query string in a url. Note that a question mark is used to separate the query string from the rest of the URL. But the question mark is not considered part of the query string (so this method should not include the question mark in the extracted query string). Note that there can never be more than one question mark in a valid URL
        Parameters:
        url -
        Returns:
        Returns the query string in the url. If there is no query string, then returns an empty string.

      • getFileName

        public static java.lang.String getFileName(java.lang.String url)
        Extracts the file name, including the file extension, from the url. Note that some urls do not include a file (the url may represent a folder on the host computer). Note that other than the host part, there should never be a dot (.) in a urlL unless it is used in the file name. So, you may want to somehow remove/replace the host part of the url before checking for a file name.
        Parameters:
        url -
        Returns:
        Returns the file name in the url. If there is no file name in the url, then returns an empty string

      • getFileExtension

        public static java.lang.String getFileExtension(java.lang.String url)
        Extracts the file extension in the url (if there is one) Note that if there is a file name in the url, it should always include the extension.
        Parameters:
        url -
        Returns:
        Returns the file extension in the url. It there is no file extension, returns an empty string

      • getPath

        public static java.lang.String getPath(java.lang.String url)
        Extracts the path portion of a url
        Parameters:
        url -
        Returns:
        Returns the path, if there is one. Returns and empty string if there is not a path in the url

      • parseQueryStringParams

        public static void parseQueryStringParams(java.lang.String url)
        Prints out the query string name and value pairs. Note that a query string is made of key/value pairs. Each pair is separated by and ampersand (&) Within each pair, the key and value are separated by an equals sign (=) For example: If this is the url: http://www.acme.com/blog/some-blog-post.html?id=7&firstName=Bob&lastName=Smith Then this would be the output printed to the console: id:7 firstName: Bob lastName: Smith If there is no query string in the url, then nothing is printed to the console.
        Parameters:
        url -
